TopicTitle: Solar panel weights and broken status

Articles.Content:
One of my crafts, the Longbow, has an escape pod with 2 ion engines and 2 of the big solar panels. With some patience it should be able to get a Kerbal safely home in case everything goes horribly wrong, possibly even from orbit of another planet. Here:

What I'm wondering is, since it has no landing gear, if I let the solar panels get ripped off on re-entry, will that mean less weight and therefore a softer landing?
If anything it would mean less drag and a harder landing. I highly advise putting some chutes on it.

It very clearly has a chute on it.

I'm honestly not sure if there is any "residual mass" if the panels break off. Given that the panels are a significant portion of the craft's mass I'd say go for it - try and see.

Even if they have 100% mass after breaking, though, I'm sure you'll still have a safe landing. That thing barely has any mass compared to some other things that land on a single chute.

=Smidge=
There's one on the nose, you just can't see it well from that angle.

There's one on the nose, you just can't see it well from that angle.

Ah, ok. You should be fine then, and in that case Yes, broken solar panel results in less overall mass, which means softer landing.

It looks like it already has a parachute on the nose, so that shouldn't be a problem. (EDIT: Multi-ninja'd)

I've never noticed any substantial performance difference between broken and unbroken solar panels affecting atmospheric drag, but it sounds like an interesting thing to test.
